image.altText: A man with a bushy beard stands among vines

props.synopsis: Wine grape growers in some of Australia's largest and most renowned regions say freezing overnight lows have wiped out whole crops — but the lower yields could lead to "more balanced and elegant flavour".

title.children: Grape growers are reeling from crop losses from frost — but how will the wine be impacted?

image.altText: graphic of different number plates under the black and white number plate 8

props.synopsis: A rare South Australian number plate has sold for a staggering $2.3 million in a "hectic" online auction.

title.children: Number 8 number plate sells for 'price of a nice villa' after 11th hour bidding war

image.altText: Paddock of black cattle eating hay.

props.synopsis: South Australia's South East is known for its reliable rainfall and good farming land, but producers say they are struggling to grow enough feed for their livestock after a dry start to 2024.

title.children: These paddocks may look lush, but farmers here are turning to charity to feed their animals

image.altText: A Port Adelaide AFL player grimaces taking a high mark as a Hawthorn defender tackles him around the ribs.

props.synopsis: Port Adelaide vice-captain Zak Butters, troubled by sore ribs, is confident he can again push through pain in the preliminary final against Sydney.

title.children: Butters plans to crash through pain barrier in Power prelim

image.altText: Hundreds of people gather outside a hospital between ambulances

props.synopsis: Lebanon's Health Ministry says a child is among those killed by a wave of exploding pagers which the militant group Hezbollah uses to communicate.

title.children: Exploding pagers wound thousands in Lebanon as Hezbollah says Israel will get 'fair punishment'

image.altText: A man is led out of a house in handcuffs.

props.synopsis: An Australian man has been arrested and charged over allegedly running an encrypted communications network tailored specifically for the use of criminal organisations.

title.children: Syndicate 'dismantled' as AFP raids target Australian creator of app for criminals

image.altText: Kitchen bench top

props.synopsis: Australia is the first country to prohibit fake stone, as the final step in a national crackdown on the deadly dust disease silicosis.

title.children: Fake kitchen stone to be stopped at border from January 1

image.altText: An ambulance drives up toward a group of people standing at the entrance of a hospital

props.synopsis: Lebanese militant group Hezbollah has vowed "punishment" against Israel over a wave of pager detonations in the country's south and east that killed at least nine people.

title.children: Hezbollah blames Israel after synchronised pager explosions injure 2,800 and kill nine

image.altText: A composite of two white men wearing suits. One is older, with glasses and a tie. One is younger with no tie or glasses.

props.synopsis: Labor senators accuse the Coalition and Greens of using "procedural tricks" to avoid being forced to formally record their opposition to the Help to Buy initiative.

title.children: Labor's housing policy was likely to be voted down — until they couldn't bring on the vote

image.altText: A still from a video appearing to show a fighter plane approaching another aircraft

props.synopsis: The 2022 incident involved a People's Liberation Army aircraft firing flares near the RAAF plane, before cutting in front of it and releasing "chaff" into its flight path.

title.children: Video emerges appearing to show 'dangerous' Chinese intercept of 'enemy' Australian aircraft

image.altText: A silhouetted hand holding an iPhone with the Instagram logo on it

props.synopsis: Instagram is introducing automatic "teen accounts" for underage users from today in Australia, the US, the UK and Canada, limiting the content available to people aged under 18.

title.children: Tough new restrictions will be introduced for all under 18 Instagram users from today

image.altText: Troy Bell walks outside a court building holding a note pad.

props.synopsis: The defence lawyer for independent MP Troy Bell says the case against the politician is "misguided and misleading".

title.children: Fraud case against MP has 'more holes than a Balfours crumpet', defence lawyer says

image.altText: man in blue blazaer in front of australian flag

props.synopsis: In his early 30s, Tom Venning would become the youngest person to hold the federal seat of Grey if elected. He is the nephew of Ivan Venning, the former Liberal politician who held the state seat of Schubert for 17 years.

title.children: Tom Venning, nephew of former MP Ivan, announced as Liberal candidate for SA's largest federal seat

image.altText: A sporting coach at a media conference.

props.synopsis: Despite regular rumblings about his job security, Port Adelaide's Ken Hinkley has an impressive coaching record — and it is easy to forget the challenge that confronted him when he arrived at the club a dozen seasons ago.

title.children: AFL coaching can be cruel, but Ken Hinkley helped the Power tear up its tarps

image.altText: A woman in a wedding dress and holding a bouquet stands beside a man in a jacket and tie outside a gift shop

props.synopsis: We've crunched the numbers for more than 43,000 job combinations and 2.8 million couples (including 31,600 same-sex couples). Turns out it's not just lawyers, doctors or teachers who stick to their own when it comes to love.

title.children: Who you'll probably marry, based on your job

image.altText: Teal PMs Allegra Spender, Monique Ryan, Sophie Scamps, Kylea Tink, Kate Chaney and Zali Steggall at a press conference

props.synopsis: We live in an age that favours disruptors. In politics, in business, in media, in art and even sport. And there's precious little evidence to suggest that we're finished with them yet.

title.children: For better or worse, the Teals have been stirring up the back bench

image.altText: A graphic showing a bottle of pills, three dollar signs and a question mark against a pink background

props.synopsis: Experts are warning of an explosion in ineffective and potentially harmful menopause supplements, with a parliamentary inquiry into menopause due to report this week. Here's what you need to know.

title.children: 'At best, they did nothing, at worst, they made things worse': The menopause products 'extensively exploiting' women

image.altText: Fuel pumps

props.synopsis: Motorists can expect further reprieve at the petrol bowser with analysts predicting continued falls in the price of oil. But economists say while falling prices are good for consumers, it won't lower underlying inflation as far as the Reserve Bank wants it to, meaning interest rate cuts are still unlikely until next year.

title.children: Why the price of unleaded petrol will keep falling in the coming weeks

image.altText: Three women with their faces covered sit at a table and draw on paper

props.synopsis: Women living under a regime which banned them from using their voice in public risk punishment to tell the world the brutal, bleak truth of life in Afghanistan.

title.children: Afghan women's mental health deteriorates under new laws banning the sound of their voices

image.altText: A portrait of a doctor in a consultation room.

props.synopsis: Health professionals and teachers want to do more to identify and help children and adults experiencing violence at home.

title.children: As many as one in two children are growing up in violent homes, research shows

image.altText: Rebecca Boehm stares glumly out kitchen window of her Bentley apartment.

props.synopsis: The reality of owning a strata-managed apartment after having saved for it for over a decade has been nothing short of a nightmare for single Perth mother and primary school teacher Rebecca Boehm.

title.children: Rebecca saved for 10 years to afford her dream home, but living in it has become a nightmare

image.altText: A woman pours a shot of liquor into a glass.

props.synopsis: Holly still has scars on her back from an alleged assault by her manager at a Sydney Bar owned by Swillhouse. When she reported it, she was horrified by the response.

title.children: Female worker asked to fix bar's 'frat-boy' culture after reporting alleged assaults by manager

image.altText: A graphic of a scientist's gloved hand holding a tube in front of a water facility

props.synopsis: The ABC can reveal that the state's health authority is now offering local councils help to test for PFAS in drinking water supplies, as scientists flag there is a knowledge gap in the size and spread of "forever chemicals" across the state.

title.children: Water scientists concerned PFAS 'knowledge gap' in drinking water supplies may be putting people at risk

image.altText: A court sketch of Ryan W. Routh, suspected of attempting to assassinate Donald Trump.

props.synopsis: The suspect in an apparent assassination attempt on Donald Trump has appeared in court. This is what we learned from Mr Routh's first court appearance, documents provided to the court, and what could happen next.

title.children: What the court documents tell us about the apparent second attempt on Trump's life

image.altText: A large crowd of people, including some holding a large banner saying 'Thank You Glasgow'

props.synopsis: The Scottish Government announces its support for a proposal that would give the ailing event a lifeline, as its revealed Commonwealth Games Australia will help foot the bill and chip in around $4.5 million.

title.children: Glasgow to host 2026 Commonwealth Games Victoria pulled out of, after 'generous' contribution from Australia

image.altText: People walk across the street towards Flinders Street Station.

props.synopsis: Economists are warning unemployment rates could go through the roof if "labour hoarding" is proven among Australian firms.

title.children: There is one 'precarious' reason why Australia's unemployment rate hasn't sky-rocketed, economists say

image.altText: A man looks at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: A lacklustre session on Wall Street is likely to send Australian stocks lower, while traders are betting the US Federal Reserve will deliver a supersized interest rate cut. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX to fall ahead of US Fed interest rate decision, Wall Street nearly unchanged

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Business Council slams PM on policies that make success 'taboo'
Why are fuel prices likely to keep falling in coming weeks?

image.altText: Sean Combs, wearing a black jacket, looks neutrally off camera in front of plastered logos.

props.synopsis: The charges against the high-profile hip-hop mogul come after a number of other lawsuits accusing him of physical and sexual abuse.

title.children: Sean 'Diddy' Combs charged with sex trafficking and racketeering in United States

image.altText: Gisele Pelicot speaks to a bank of microphones wearing round, brown sunglasses with people standing behind her looking on

props.synopsis: Dominique Pelicot's testimony is set to be key for the other 50 men accused of raping his then wife over nearly a decade.

title.children: A French man admits in court to drugging his wife so that he and dozens of men could rape her

image.altText: A woman with short grey hair stands at a lectern looking angry and hurt.

props.synopsis: When Harriet Spring publicly admitted she'd lost a $1.6 million inheritance to scammers, she had low expectations for both financial compensation and criminal consequences, but over the past week there's been progress on both fronts.

title.children: Woman who lost $1.6 million to scammers campaigns for change as seven people allegedly involved are arrested

image.altText: Nicho Hynes prepares to pass the ball

props.synopsis: Nicho Hynes has conceded he may forever be known as a player who has failed to win big games, but insists his finals performance against Melbourne was not as bad as made out.

title.children: Nicho Hynes aware of being 'ridiculed' as rugby league icon calls for axing after another finals flop

image.altText: A young child sleeps and a sleeping mother is just visible behind them, in a room dimly lit.

props.synopsis: Parents who co-sleep with their young children can face judgement and criticism, especially when the children are primary-school aged. Yet, most people in the world co-sleep with their children at some point. Here's what some of those parents get out of it.

title.children: How old is too old for co-sleeping? The answer may divide parents

image.altText: Danielle Wood productivity commission

props.synopsis: Productivity Commission chair Danielle Wood says she welcomes concessions made by the Albanese government to put clearer scrutiny of proposals for industry assistance into its Future Made in Australia legislation.

title.children: Productivity Commission welcomes additional scrutiny of Future Made in Australia projects

image.altText: A woman with red hair sits at her home computer.

props.synopsis: Tech giants have split over WFH rights, with many Australian businesses adopting hybrid approaches to when and how people need to attend work.

title.children: Amazon orders all workers back into office as some Australian companies embrace flexibility

image.altText: A woman carries a child on her shoulders while walking through floodwater in front of homes made with wood and iron sheets

props.synopsis: More than 200 people have been killed in floods and landslides sparked by the storm across Myanmar, with some 240,000 others displaced by the disaster.

title.children: Death toll from Typhoon Yagi rises past 500 amid floods and landslides in Myanmar
